commit_message:
Update manila environment file names

to eliminate special 'docker' names.

Containerized manila is now the standard way to deploy
so we can avoid confusion by just using the regular
manila environment file names for these rather than having
some manila environment files with 'docker' in their names.

Note that we are using the content of
environments/manila-cephfsnative-config-docker.yaml
for
environments/manila-cephfsnative-config.yaml.  This resolves an
issue wherein the parameters in the latter file were not updated
when support for the CephFS-NFS back end was added [1].

Closes-Bug: #1782622

[1] Ib408c7827e5fba0c1b01388db26363806fc64370

Change-Id: I08431d848158846a434fecc98d3bee838c7fad68

subject: Add support for Neutron agent api
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 5756, 'name': 'Terry Wilson', 'email': 'twilson@redhat.com', 'username': 'otherwiseguy'}, {'_account_id': 6773, 'name': 'Lucas Alvares Gomes', 'email': 'lucasagomes@gmail.com', 'username': 'lucasagomes'}, {'_account_id': 8788, 'name': 'Miguel Angel Ajo', 'email': 'mangelajo@redhat.com', 'username': 'mangelajo'}, {'_account_id': 8871, 'name': 'Elastic Recheck', 'username': 'elasticrecheck'}, {'_account_id': 10237, 'name': 'Numan Siddique', 'email': 'nusiddiq@redhat.com', 'username': 'numansiddique'}, {'_account_id': 10267, 'name': 'venkata anil', 'email': 'anilvenkata@redhat.com', 'username': 'anil'}, {'_account_id': 13995, 'name': 'Nate Johnston', 'email': 'nate.johnston@redhat.com', 'username': 'natejohnston'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23804, 'name': 'Daniel Alvarez', 'email': 'dalvarez@redhat.com', 'username': 'dalvarez'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 5756, 'date': '2018-06-26 22:41:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 5756, 'date': '2018-06-26 22:55:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

This is admittedly a hack, but I think it is a thoughtful hack. Even if other drivers look at it and try something similar, it should work as long as they follow its example. Ideally, I'd like to see neutron's ml2 have a shim itself for bypassing the db handling to allow API calls to be handled by drivers. This would allow a plugin to not have to worry about syncing to the neutron database and being the source of truth itself, while still allowing multi-driver support.

Since that would be a much bigger project and we had a request to add agent API support to networking-ovn, I thought this could at least be a PoC for a larger addition to neutron itself while still being able to add the simple feature locally here.

This does raise the issue of testing. I think I can add 'agent' to the list of extensions supported to at least enable the tempest tests, though I haven't looked over them yet and they may test things we don't support like deleting/updating agents."}, {'account_id': 8871, 'date': '2018-06-27 02:42:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I noticed Zuul failed, I think you hit bug(s):

- networking-ovn-dsvm-functional-py35: https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1686542
- networking-ovn-dsvm-functional: unrecognized error
- networking-ovn-rally-task: unrecognized error
- networking-ovn-tempest-dsvm-ovs-release: unrecognized error

Some of the tests failed in a way that we did not understand. Please help us classify these issues so that they can be part of Elastic Recheck http://status.openstack.org/elastic-recheck/
For more details on this and other bugs, please see http://status.openstack.org/elastic-recheck/'}, {'account_id': 5756, 'date': '2018-06-27 05:52:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 8871, 'date': '2018-06-27 08:24:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I noticed Zuul failed, I think you hit bug(s):

- networking-ovn-dsvm-functional-py35: https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1686542
- networking-ovn-dsvm-functional: unrecognized error
- networking-ovn-rally-task: unrecognized error
- networking-ovn-tempest-dsvm-ovs-release: unrecognized error

Some of the tests failed in a way that we did not understand. Please help us classify these issues so that they can be part of Elastic Recheck http://status.openstack.org/elastic-recheck/
For more details on this and other bugs, please see http://status.openstack.org/elastic-recheck/'}, {'account_id': 23804, 'date': '2018-06-27 08:38:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I like the "hack" :) I have a few comments:

1. This is updating the state only when there's transactions. There's an scenario where ovn-controller can crash, OVS got restarted (installed flows go away) so instances are essentially unreachable and we won't notice through the Agent API. We should update the NB db periodically to cover this. I'd be good for a follow up patch though :)

2. We are lacking OVN metadata agent here. 

3. A good point that we just discussed offline: if a chassis is removed, then the agente would always show as dead so we may want to support the delete operation which should delete the Chassis entry from the SB database.

Let's see what others think but thanks a lot Terry for taking this up! Good job!'}, {'account_id': 5756, 'date': '2018-06-28 08:57:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 5756, 'date': '2018-07-02 09:16:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 5756, 'date': '2018-07-04 10:55:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 5756, 'date': '2018-07-06 09:07:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Patch Set 4 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 5756, 'date': '2018-07-06 10:42:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 5756, 'date': '2018-07-06 14:02:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 8871, 'date': '2018-07-06 16:10:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

I noticed Zuul failed, I think you hit bug(s):

For more details on this and other bugs, please see http://status.openstack.org/elastic-recheck/'}, {'account_id': 5756, 'date': '2018-07-11 14:29:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 5756, 'date': '2018-07-16 17:36:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 5756, 'date': '2018-07-16 21:17:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 5756, 'date': '2018-07-17 13:15:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 5756, 'date': '2018-07-17 16:11:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 5756, 'date': '2018-07-17 20:25:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 8788, 'date': '2018-07-18 07:18:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Patch Set 11 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 8788, 'date': '2018-07-18 07:21:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12: Code-Review+2

I like the patch, although the neutron folks found the common hook point interesting, we could follow up with that. We may need it to ensure we have a way to report bandwidth on 'agents' at some point, that also requires ovn-controller reporting it though."}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2018-07-18 11:59:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12: Code-Review-1

(6 comments)

Thanks Terry!

It's looking good already few comments here and there, mostly nits/suggestions."}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2018-07-18 12:01:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

Btw I tested it locally and it works:

[stack@host11 devstack]$ openstack network agent list
+--------------------------------------+----------------------+-----------------------------------------------+-------------------+-------+-------+----------------+
| ID                                   | Agent Type           | Host                                          | Availability Zone | Alive | State | Binary         |
+--------------------------------------+----------------------+-----------------------------------------------+-------------------+-------+-------+----------------+
| 23bd71cd-f35a-4325-93c2-8e7cfdd71998 | OVN Controller agent | host11.beaker.tripleo.lab.eng.rdu2.redhat.com | n/a               | :-)   | UP    | ovn-controller |
+--------------------------------------+----------------------+-----------------------------------------------+-------------------+-------+-------+----------------'}, {'account_id': 8788, 'date': '2018-07-18 12:29:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12: -Code-Review

(3 comments)

Based on lucas comments I'm removing the +2"}, {'account_id': 5756, 'date': '2018-07-18 13:05:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2018-07-18 13:17:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 5756, 'date': '2018-07-18 13:34:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 8788, 'date': '2018-07-18 13:38:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2018-07-18 13:44:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

Thanks Terry,

I would love to see some tests on this but we can work that out on a separated patch.'}, {'account_id': 10237, 'date': '2018-07-18 14:29:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

I tested it locally and it works as expected.

There is one corner case. In case ovn-controller segfaults or some one kills the process, then "agent list" will not be able to detect the failure of the ovn-controller until a transaction happens to the north db and this behavior has nothing to do with this patch. That's the drawback of using the "nb_cfg" approach.'}, {'account_id': 10237, 'date': '2018-07-18 14:32:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 5756, 'date': '2018-07-18 15:56:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

Numan, I could modify the patch to make the get_agents() do a chassis_list() command, which would actually increment nb_cfg on the read operation which would always give us up-to-date results. I just worried that there could be a lot of delay and it would open up a race condition--or if we just waited for the propagation to happen before returning, then the delay might be greater than the ovsdb_timeout, etc. In any real-world scenario I figured there would be a tool to actually restart failed processes, so maybe it wasn't worth the work to handle the edge case (and since all of the flows are there, are things really broken before we try an operation and it fails? :p)

There's definitely room for improvement there and can use all of the suggestions that people can come up with. :)"}, {'account_id': 10237, 'date': '2018-07-24 09:42:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

> Numan, I could modify the patch to make the get_agents() do a
 > chassis_list() command, which would actually increment nb_cfg on
 > the read operation which would always give us up-to-date results. I
 > just worried that there could be a lot of delay and it would open
 > up a race condition--or if we just waited for the propagation to
 > happen before returning, then the delay might be greater than the
 > ovsdb_timeout, etc. In any real-world scenario I figured there
 > would be a tool to actually restart failed processes, so maybe it
 > wasn't worth the work to handle the edge case (and since all of the
 > flows are there, are things really broken before we try an
 > operation and it fails? :p)
 > 
 > There's definitely room for improvement there and can use all of
 > the suggestions that people can come up with. :)

Totally agree :)."}]

commit_message:
Add support for Neutron agent api

Instead of polling and writing updates to the Neutron DB agents
table, this patch replaces the neutron plugin agent api methods,
being sure to maintain support for multiple drivers.

Partial-Bug: #1719574
Change-Id: I43e8b0a7914e3626dd848b04fdfc54fb0351bae6

commit_message:
Revert "Initial support for adding cluster nodes to an existing cluster"

This reverts commit 03391e07ea608aedb0716d392c169d13273694e1.

This has broken puppet-tripleo unit tests as we appear to be
executing crm calls.

http://logs.openstack.org/58/583658/3/check/puppet-openstack-unit-4.8-centos-7/58d8a84/job-output.txt.gz#_2018-07-23_18_25_32_550205

Change-Id: Iaf21af2000ce6f9376a50aea6776d7263f530357

After things get moving again we should refactor and work out something to use this way, which is more correct."}, {'account_id': 9712, 'date': '2018-06-07 10:58:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 15054, 'date': '2018-06-07 10:58:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

 > https://review.openstack.org/#/c/572788/

 > After things get moving again we should refactor and work out
 > something to use this way, which is more correct.

++, backwards compatibility should be considered. for the users who changed the default value of the options [1], this patch will break them.
[1]: https://github.com/openstack/keystoneauth/blob/master/keystoneauth1/loading/session.py#L170-L183

A solution I can think (pseudo-code):

loading.register_session_conf_options(cfg.CONF, _KEYSTONE_SESSION_GROUP)
for opt in CONF['keystone_authtoken']:
    if opt != <default_value> and CONF[_KEYSTONE_SESSION_GROUP].get(opt.name).value != opt.value:
	    LOG.warning('something to operators that the options in _KEYSTONE_SESSION_GROUP should be configured as well....')
		CONF.set_override(opt.name, opt.value, group=_KEYSTONE_SESSION_GROUP)"}, {'account_id': 7065, 'date': '2018-06-07 12:06:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 21970, 'date': '2018-06-07 13:06:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 21970, 'date': '2018-06-07 14:38:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 21970, 'date': '2018-06-07 14:49:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I tried to implement the pseudo code from @wangxiyuan. It's very much not clear how can it be done clearly. Below is a huge hack. I couldn't get it to work as it is not clear where it could be inserted. Right after the session opts addition is not the right place because it seems like the config file is still not parsed at that point. Corrections could be made only after https://github.com/openstack/mistral/blob/master/mistral/cmd/launch.py#L181 is executed.

for opt, value in CONF[_KEYSTONE_AUTHTOKEN_GROUP].items():
    if opt in CONF[_KEYSTONE_AUTHTOKEN_GROUP] and opt in CONF[_KEYSTONE_SESSION_GROUP]:
        if value != CONF[_KEYSTONE_AUTHTOKEN_GROUP]._group._opts[opt]['opt'].default:
            if CONF[_KEYSTONE_SESSION_GROUP][opt] != value:
                #LOG.warning('something to operators that the options in _KEYSTONE_SESSION_GROUP should be configured as well....')
                CONF.set_override(opt.name, opt.value, group=_KEYSTONE_SESSION_GROUP)"}, {'account_id': 15054, 'date': '2018-07-19 09:00:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 21970, 'date': '2018-07-19 11:48:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2

commit_message:
Use register_session_conf_options API

Using this API is needed to correctly initialize the configuration.

[keystone_authtoken] group is used for keystonemiddleware to validating
token.

The new [keystone] group is used for keystoneauth to initialization
the keystone session.

Co-Authored-By: wangxiyuan<wangxiyuan@huawei.com>

Change-Id: Ie3ab512b0ab42c0f97b3099e0787f4edee08ddce
Partial-Bug: #1775140

[{'created': '2018-05-31 12:13:45.000000000', 'message': "WIP write /etc/tripleo-release to overcloud nodes

There are many ways this could happen - with an rpm, via a task in
tripleo-heat-templates. Each has pros/cons. IMO client is the
best place/representative of what you are doing. Mixed version
deployments is one problem not yet solved here.

This uses the existing run_on_nodes which invokes mistral. We
do this after the last 'success' is printed in deploy,update|
ffwd-upgrade|upgrade converge. Posting for discussion&ideas

The content of the release is read from the tripleo heat templates
used in the given operation, added in related review below.

Change-Id: Ic8f9d8cc1806341eaeb511ddd3ca675a84471b9f
Related: Id034c29d496bdfb48933d9e9113dc294ba8fbfed tripleo-heat-templates
Related-Bug: #TODO
"}]
commit_message:
WIP write /etc/tripleo-release to overcloud nodes

There are many ways this could happen - with an rpm, via a task in
tripleo-heat-templates. Each has pros/cons. IMO client is the
best place/representative of what you are doing. Mixed version
deployments is one problem not yet solved here.

This uses the existing run_on_nodes which invokes mistral. We
do this after the last 'success' is printed in deploy,update|
ffwd-upgrade|upgrade converge. Posting for discussion&ideas

The content of the release is read from the tripleo heat templates
used in the given operation, added in related review below.

Change-Id: Ic8f9d8cc1806341eaeb511ddd3ca675a84471b9f
Related: Id034c29d496bdfb48933d9e9113dc294ba8fbfed tripleo-heat-templates
Related-Bug: #TODO

commit_message:
Remove unnecessary default variables

Remove unusable variables as well as change
default passwords for influxdb users (perister and
api). These users needs use the values provided by
user_secrets.yml.

Change-Id: I02a4fa5df919d48d6e0671510793bc41143711d5

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-17 18:38:05.000000000', 'message': "Change the OVN environment files with hw offload to deploy OVN pacemaker bundles

The commit with change id [1] deleted all the OVN environment files which deployed
OVN dbs in non HA. But few environment files related to hw offload were missed out.

This patch renames these environment files and changes OVNDBs service to OVN pacemaker
bundles.

It also sets 'KernelIpNonLocalBind: 1'.

Related-bug: #1781585
Closes-bug: #1779123
Change-Id: I16c3b111e8d2423af3c0acc56db68a51c096a9cb
"}]
commit_message:
Change the OVN environment files with hw offload to deploy OVN pacemaker bundles

The commit with change id [1] deleted all the OVN environment files which deployed
OVN dbs in non HA. But few environment files related to hw offload were missed out.

This patch renames these environment files and changes OVNDBs service to OVN pacemaker
bundles.

It also sets 'KernelIpNonLocalBind: 1'.

Related-bug: #1781585
Closes-bug: #1779123
Change-Id: I16c3b111e8d2423af3c0acc56db68a51c096a9cb

subject: Fix for proper LVM support
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 6133, 'name': 'yolanda.robla', 'email': 'yroblamo@redhat.com', 'username': 'yolanda.robla'}, {'_account_id': 7118, 'name': 'Ian Wienand', 'email': 'iwienand@redhat.com', 'username': 'iwienand'}, {'_account_id': 10118, 'name': 'IBM PowerKVM CI', 'email': 'kvmpower@linux.vnet.ibm.com', 'username': 'powerkvm', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 19578, 'name': 'Olivier Bourdon', 'email': 'olivierbourdon38@gmail.com', 'username': 'olivierbourdon38'}, {'_account_id': 21741, 'name': 'Andreas Florath', 'email': 'andreas@florath.net', 'username': 'florath'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23181, 'name': 'RDO Third Party CI', 'email': 'dmsimard+rdothirdparty@redhat.com', 'username': 'rdothirdparty', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 19578, 'date': '2018-06-18 15:21:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2018-06-21 10:42:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

(2 comments)

Thanks for looking at this.  I don't have that great feeling when something just seems to naturally fit.  These checks all potentially break on users at like the last step, probably leaving a bunch of stuff still mounted.  we really try to have things like packages sorted out with correct dependencies.  i understand this is a bit weird as you don't find out you have lvm till you're in the block device layers..."}, {'account_id': 19578, 'date': '2018-06-21 11:22:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 19578, 'date': '2018-06-21 11:23:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Many thanks for the review & comments Ian'}, {'account_id': 21741, 'date': '2018-06-23 16:50:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(8 comments)

IMHO you are mixing up three different tasks here:

* Checks for things that are already known to block device layer
* Bootloader
* initramfs

I'd prefer to split this into parts."}, {'account_id': 19578, 'date': '2018-06-25 06:02:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(8 comments)

Thanks for the comments Andreas. My answers and further questions inline'}, {'account_id': 19578, 'date': '2018-06-25 06:31:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Having looked back at https://review.openstack.org/#/c/562004/ I now remember
that in my case and as i mentioned in my previous comment I was using dracut and not initramfs-tools, the call to initrd regeneration was failing because utility was not there.
As for the other reasons of failure I can not tell.
At this point the only thing this can make me think is that splitting stuff between boot loader and other elements like debootstrap might not be so easy
I will do further testing later this week on other distributions to see impact of this change
Thanks again for pointing all this out'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2018-06-28 05:47:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

one other thought; I've had a stab at cleaning some of this up before with Ifb107796cdb6748430a124bf13ced93db9689bff.  I wouldn't insist, but basing this ontop of that, and moving a lot of this into a function() might make this feel a little more modular"}, {'account_id': 19578, 'date': '2018-07-01 16:33:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 19578, 'date': '2018-07-01 16:37:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Finally decided to move this code as a separate DIB element so that it complies with comments and avoids misbehaviour in existing usages'}, {'account_id': 19578, 'date': '2018-07-02 04:22:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 19578, 'date': '2018-07-06 06:37:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Ian, Andreas, does the new separation as a specific element better fit your requirements ? Many thanks for the reviews.'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2018-07-09 06:29:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I would really like Yolanda's input on this ...

we already put a caveat on the LVM instructions in the user guide about using dracut-regenerate to make sure you've got the LVM modules with [1].  I don't suppose this is really that much different?  if this is what we want to do, adding this as more verbose instructions there would be helpful

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/diskimage-builder/latest/user_guide/building_an_image.html#module-lvm"}, {'account_id': 19578, 'date': '2018-07-09 07:34:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Ian, thanks for the comment and indeed this is exactly why I added Yolanda in the list of reviewers for this patchset in the very begining as she was the one who bootstrapped me with a working LVM solution.'}, {'account_id': 6133, 'date': '2018-07-09 11:10:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 19578, 'date': '2018-07-09 14:10:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 19578, 'date': '2018-07-09 14:13:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 19578, 'date': '2018-07-09 14:14:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Done, many thanks for the review Yolanda'}, {'account_id': 19578, 'date': '2018-07-09 14:15:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Published edit on patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 19578, 'date': '2018-07-09 14:16:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Published edit on patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 6133, 'date': '2018-07-10 06:39:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2018-07-10 07:12:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

One more thing, if I can -- can we confirm this works with the stack of patches down from 

 https://review.openstack.org/#/c/579102/

this series came from when we identified that we were removing the loop device *before* we used kpartx to remove the partitions.  that somehow seemed to work, mostly, but was wrong.  I'd like to make sure that if we merge this and all that we have something that works...

There is one more patch on top of that

 https://review.openstack.org/#/c/579059/

which is not really as critical, it just modifies the graph layout, but functionally should be the same."}, {'account_id': 19578, 'date': '2018-07-10 07:43:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Ian, no pb in testing this later today on my side
Just to be use I fully got what you needed, you'd like the test to be carried out including all
6 patches related to https://review.openstack.org/#/c/579059/ plus this new lvm stuff
to see if this still works right ?"}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2018-07-11 05:52:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

> you'd like the test to be carried out including all 6 patches related to 
> https://review.openstack.org/#/c/579059/ plus this new lvm stuff to see if this still works right ?

yes please, i'd feel much better merging all these at once knowing that it all works

i'd also like to see this update the main documentation along where we give the dracut-regenerate caveats

longer term, an LVM booting test would probably be best.  The path to this is probably 1) get zuulv3 jobs in 2) move the boot tests from nodepool into dib repo 3) create a variant that builds images with a lvm backend.  that's quite some work, however"}, {'account_id': 19578, 'date': '2018-07-11 09:58:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Finished testing this patch on top of 6 others + https://review.openstack.org/559485 (;-)) due to the fact that I am running this on Ubuntu Xenial system. The following 4 images where generated successfully and booted in KVM to seek correct functionality
2 images (Ubuntu xenial, CentOS 7) x 2 partitioning profiles (1 flat, 1 LVM)

disk-image-create -o on-os-ubuntu-xenial.qcow2 -t qcow2 --image-size 60 -p 
python,python3-yaml,dnsutils,net-tools,netcat,iputils-ping,traceroute,curl,lvm2,xfsprogs,initramfs-tools ubuntu-minimal bootloader enable-serial-console dhcp-all-interfaces devuser openssh-server lvm

commit_message:
Fix for proper LVM support

Without this fix, a LVM based ubuntu-minimal image will fail
booting due to the fact that the boot process will not be able
to retrieve the root filesystem using LABEL=(cloud)img-rootfs

Change-Id: If4ecf65868563f7b799160a58af6312bedf956bf

for quickstart.sh. Remove it because failing jobs in ci.centos

[{'created': '2018-07-18 14:03:58.000000000', 'message': "Map instances to cell_v2 only once.

If nova-manage cell_v2 create_cell returns 2, it's because the cell already
exists and all instances are correctly mapped to the cell. The cell_v2
map_instances doesn't need to run.

Change-Id: I38002a18dff4dbd44bd3df9e1969c9d50ab12705
Related-Bug: 1729661
"}]
commit_message:
Map instances to cell_v2 only once.

If nova-manage cell_v2 create_cell returns 2, it's because the cell already
exists and all instances are correctly mapped to the cell. The cell_v2
map_instances doesn't need to run.

Change-Id: I38002a18dff4dbd44bd3df9e1969c9d50ab12705
Related-Bug: 1729661

commit_message:
add py3-dev tox target and update lower constraints zuul job

This patch adds a py3-dev tox target for running py3 UTs locally.
It also updates the local .zuul.yaml for a neutron-vpnaas specific
lower constraints job that ensure neutron/master is installed.

Change-Id: Iab9f134b17b56d765d5ac523d9b5a4b4d4e00fb7
Partial-Bug: #1779335

subject: Ensure "elastic_thread_pool_size" is cast to int
messages: [{'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2018-07-24 05:31:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2018-07-24 06:13:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-24 05:31:06.000000000', 'message': 'Ensure "elastic_thread_pool_size" is cast to int

The variable elastic_thread_pool_size is expected to be an integer
however setting it as a fact and using it later results in it being a
string which creates unexpected results when the string has math applied
to it.

Change-Id: I339792c80378c86f785462a318a2565e946c7515
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Ensure "elastic_thread_pool_size" is cast to int

The variable elastic_thread_pool_size is expected to be an integer
however setting it as a fact and using it later results in it being a
string which creates unexpected results when the string has math applied
to it.

Change-Id: I339792c80378c86f785462a318a2565e946c7515
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

This patchset adds an RBAC overview documentation section dedicated
to:

* Defining what RBAC is
* Policy in code and validation info related to it
* Custom policies and validation info related to it
* Multiple policies and validation info related to it
* Error codes
* Glossary

This way, users can learn about what RBAC is from a high level
and how Patrole uses validation to validate that it is working
correctly.

Change-Id: Ib411e4d06210135f7bd1cb90d5b6d59da2e5d076
'}]
commit_message:
Docs: Add RBAC overview documentation

This patchset adds an RBAC overview documentation section dedicated
to:

* Defining what RBAC is
* Policy in code and validation info related to it
* Custom policies and validation info related to it
* Multiple policies and validation info related to it
* Error codes
* Glossary

This way, users can learn about what RBAC is from a high level
and how Patrole uses validation to validate that it is working
correctly.

Change-Id: Ib411e4d06210135f7bd1cb90d5b6d59da2e5d076

[1]. This patch updates the neutron-lib required version to match
neutron [1] in prep for the Rocky release.

commit_message:
update requirements for neutron-lib 1.18.0

Neutron-lib 1.18.0 is our Rocky RC and is already being used by neutron
[1]. This patch updates the neutron-lib required version to match
neutron [1] in prep for the Rocky release.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/583671/

Change-Id: Iee7a1ab3559b3ef58354f90774c2854e41dc18ae

commit_message:
Fixup ceph.conf templating

Ensure that code snips don't slurp to much whitespace,
resulting in a broken set of keys within the generated
configuration file.

Closes-Bug: 1783195
Change-Id: I7cfe026c60c04ac19741a3a2b364cec3fb8746ba
(cherry picked from commit 2f148f26b6228bcac7aa14ad69ab565de61b2b2b)

commit_message:
Fix directory structure

This patch creates
  - `blazar/api/v1/leases`
  - `blazar/tests/api/v1/leases`
  - `blazar/manager/leases`
and move related files there to keep symmetric
structure between oshosts and leases API.

This patch also moves test_physical_host_plugin.py from
`blazar/tests/plugins/` to `blazar/tests/plugins/oshosts/`.

Change-Id: Ib5ae4e291a9e47459f7aeee3d7570688bd8b1648

commit_message:
Add connbeat

Connbeat adds the ability to deploy connection tracking. This change
adds this community beat to the stack.

Change-Id: I5395e6d0a895bb9db94d4647d4ff26ee8e90b380
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-24 07:14:55.000000000', 'message': 'Adding affinity/anti-affinity policy for VDU spec

This proposal describes the plan to introduce Affinity/Anti-affinity
policies for VDUs into VNFD template. Affinity policy enables to place
VDUs into the same Compute node and Anti-affinity policy enables to
force VDUs placed into different Compute nodes.

Change-Id: I2bf432dd91c9da83d9bd38bbe5879cc1c0b1144e

commit_message:
Adding affinity/anti-affinity policy for VDU spec

This proposal describes the plan to introduce Affinity/Anti-affinity
policies for VDUs into VNFD template. The Tacker administrator enables
the Affinity policy to place VDUs into the same Compute node and enables
Anti-affinity policy to force-place VDUs into different Compute nodes.

Change-Id: I2bf432dd91c9da83d9bd38bbe5879cc1c0b1144e
Co-Authored-By: Masataka Saito <saitomst@intellilink.co.jp>
Implements: blueprint vdu-affinity-policy

commit_message:
Revert "Add log file to tacker-server systemctl daemon script"

Due this patch there are some issue with logging:

1: No Tacker logs generating on gate.
2: No logs in journalctl
3: unable to set log location with config file.

So here reverting this patch.

Closes-Bug: #1782718

This reverts commit 7f60e64bd3cdca461e1e3b507a1b557fd3240a89.

Change-Id: I8dd56d049459037a0f5ea5fd11aaa4449fc55f0f

commit_message:
Remove deprecated CLI options

The following options were deprecated in Queens or Pike and are now
being removed:

--endpoint-type
--bypass-url
--os-auth-system

Change-Id: I3b951cc4eb3adff23f3d2cbe674971816261ef56
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

subject: Configure keepalived before rabbitmq
messages: [{'account_id': 20172, 'date': '2018-07-23 12:28:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2018-07-23 22:29:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 26431, 'date': '2018-07-24 01:00:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-23 12:28:54.000000000', 'message': "Configure keepalived before rabbitmq

Sometimes an undercloud could fail to install with the following error:
2018-05-29 12:53:17,588 INFO: May 29 12:53:08 foo.int.bar systemd[1]: Starting RabbitMQ broker...
2018-05-29 12:53:17,588 INFO: May 29 12:53:11 foo.int.bar rabbitmq-server[14327]: ERROR: epmd error for host foo: address (cannot connect to host/port)
2018-05-29 12:53:17,588 INFO: May 29 12:53:11 foo.int.bar systemd[1]: rabbitmq-server.service: main process exited, code=exited, status=1/FAILURE

1) The hostname of the box is
foo.int.bar foo

and in the hosts file we have the following entry: 192.168.248.2
192.168.248.2 foo.int.bar foo

Note: 192.168.248.2 is a VIP managed by keepalived because we configured this
undercloud to be an SSL one so we have:
undercloud_public_host = 192.168.248.2

2) At this stage we see rabbitmq-server being started:
Jan 27 06:46:31 foo.int.bar systemd[1]: Starting Flexible Branding Service...
Jan 27 06:46:31 foo.int.bar systemd[1]: epmd@0.0.0.0.socket failed to listen on sockets: Address already in use
Jan 27 06:46:31 foo.int.bar systemd[1]: Failed to listen on Erlang Port Mapper Daemon Activation Socket.
Jan 27 06:46:31 foo.int.bar systemd[1]: Unit epmd@0.0.0.0.socket entered failed state.
Jan 27 06:46:31 foo.int.bar systemd[1]: Starting Erlang Port Mapper Daemon Activation Socket.
Jan 27 06:46:31 foo.int.bar systemd[1]: Starting RabbitMQ broker...
Jan 27 06:46:34 foo.int.bar rabbitmq-server[14532]: ERROR: epmd error for host foo: address (cannot connect to host/port)

Now epmd might have already been up (and normally the failed message is
not particularly concerning). But the real problem is that we are trying
to connect to foo which maps to a VIP, but the VIP gets started only
later by keepalived:
3)
Jan 27 07:02:30 foo.int.bar Keepalived_vrrp[914]: VRRP_Instance(42) Sending/queueing gratuitous ARPs on br-ctlplane for 192.168.248.2
Jan 27 07:02:30 foo.int.bar Keepalived_vrrp[914]: Sending gratuitous ARP on br-ctlplane for 192.168.248.2

Let's make sure keepalived is up and running before rabbitmq in order to
fix this.

Change-Id: I010102b01e41610838c836a743a07be1965944d6
Closes-Bug: #1782814
(cherry picked from commit c3ccb92d64e7ee724d7d2f28d138894805d41629)
"}]
commit_message:
Configure keepalived before rabbitmq

Sometimes an undercloud could fail to install with the following error:
2018-05-29 12:53:17,588 INFO: May 29 12:53:08 foo.int.bar systemd[1]: Starting RabbitMQ broker...
2018-05-29 12:53:17,588 INFO: May 29 12:53:11 foo.int.bar rabbitmq-server[14327]: ERROR: epmd error for host foo: address (cannot connect to host/port)
2018-05-29 12:53:17,588 INFO: May 29 12:53:11 foo.int.bar systemd[1]: rabbitmq-server.service: main process exited, code=exited, status=1/FAILURE

1) The hostname of the box is
foo.int.bar foo

and in the hosts file we have the following entry: 192.168.248.2
192.168.248.2 foo.int.bar foo

Note: 192.168.248.2 is a VIP managed by keepalived because we configured this
undercloud to be an SSL one so we have:
undercloud_public_host = 192.168.248.2

2) At this stage we see rabbitmq-server being started:
Jan 27 06:46:31 foo.int.bar systemd[1]: Starting Flexible Branding Service...
Jan 27 06:46:31 foo.int.bar systemd[1]: epmd@0.0.0.0.socket failed to listen on sockets: Address already in use
Jan 27 06:46:31 foo.int.bar systemd[1]: Failed to listen on Erlang Port Mapper Daemon Activation Socket.
Jan 27 06:46:31 foo.int.bar systemd[1]: Unit epmd@0.0.0.0.socket entered failed state.
Jan 27 06:46:31 foo.int.bar systemd[1]: Starting Erlang Port Mapper Daemon Activation Socket.
Jan 27 06:46:31 foo.int.bar systemd[1]: Starting RabbitMQ broker...
Jan 27 06:46:34 foo.int.bar rabbitmq-server[14532]: ERROR: epmd error for host foo: address (cannot connect to host/port)

Now epmd might have already been up (and normally the failed message is
not particularly concerning). But the real problem is that we are trying
to connect to foo which maps to a VIP, but the VIP gets started only
later by keepalived:
3)
Jan 27 07:02:30 foo.int.bar Keepalived_vrrp[914]: VRRP_Instance(42) Sending/queueing gratuitous ARPs on br-ctlplane for 192.168.248.2
Jan 27 07:02:30 foo.int.bar Keepalived_vrrp[914]: Sending gratuitous ARP on br-ctlplane for 192.168.248.2

Let's make sure keepalived is up and running before rabbitmq in order to
fix this.

Change-Id: I010102b01e41610838c836a743a07be1965944d6
Closes-Bug: #1782814
(cherry picked from commit c3ccb92d64e7ee724d7d2f28d138894805d41629)

commit_message:
Add DockerNovaMetadataConfigImage as part of metadata httpd wsgi move

We gonna change nova metadata api to be served via httpd wsgi. Therefore
we'll have a new config volume for the nova_metadata container.

Adding DockerNovaMetadataConfigImage for this.

Change-Id: I47d79ab8e274e94cbe0d4cadd204e63cbbe3dca8

commit_message:
ansible: replace yum module by package module when possible

Problem: RHEL and CentOS8 will deprecate the usage of Yum.

From DNF release note:
DNF is the next upcoming major version of yum, a package
manager for RPM-based Linux distributions.
It roughly maintains CLI compatibility with YUM and defines a strict API for
extensions.

Solution: Use "package" Ansible module instead of "yum".

"package" module is smarter when it comes to detect with package manager
runs on the system. The goal of this patch is to support both yum/dnf
(dnf will be the default in rhel/centos 8) from a single ansible module.

Change-Id: I8e67d6f053e8790fdd0eb52a42035dca3051999e

commit_message:
Use /var/lib/mistral/<plan-name> as config-download dir

Use a consistent directory under /var/lib/mistral (which defaults to the
plan name) as the working and config-download directory in the
config_download_deploy workflow. Since the config-download directory
is now managed by git, we can re-use the same dir and preserve the
history.

Change-Id: Id639d0a99aa1103f6f9cc54de676ea8ba6111332
Closes-Bug: #1779093

/var/lib/mistral/latest-tht exists the permissions look ok (-rw-r--r--.  1 mistral mistral) except the .git/index has root owner which may be the problem? See this paste for complete list of files/permissions http://paste.openstack.org/show/725984/'}, {'account_id': 7509, 'date': '2018-07-16 19:07:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: -Code-Review

The .git/index permissions issue occurs when deployment is re-deployed on previously deployed deployment plan. This does not occur with CLI as afaik it is deleting the swift container on undeploy.

If I try to deploy with fresh deployment plan, I am still hitting the yaml error we discussed on IRC yesterday: http://paste.openstack.org/show/726041/ The <planName>-config container now correctly exists and Controller/host_prep_tasks.yaml object is correct in that container, although the file in /var/lib/mistral/<planName>/Controller/host_prep_tasks.yaml is corrupt in the same way as in the paste above'}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2018-07-17 13:04:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-07-17 13:50:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Override the default git commit message so that it's clear that the
config-download commit was run from the Mistral action.

Also, first download the existing config container if one exists. Since
the config-download dir is now managed as a git repo, we want to
preserve the git history, so we need to first reuse the existing
contents of the config container.

commit_message:
git integration for GetOvercloudConfig action

Override the default git commit message so that it's clear that the
config-download commit was run from the Mistral action.

Also, first download the existing config container if one exists. Since
the config-download dir is now managed as a git repo, we want to
preserve the git history, so we need to first reuse the existing
contents of the config container.

Change-Id: I0246918d89dfb564e3d472d4b2f517b5beaf4372

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-20 16:02:20.000000000', 'message': "Log tracebacks

Always log the traceback for unexpected exceptions. It's very difficult
to tell where the error came from with the traceback.

It seems this was the intent with
Iad9de7fab0ee740bd20f8facd49f36e6f18d2fb1, but
traceback.format_exception doesn't actually print/log anything, it
returns a list of strings, which are just lost if not actually
saved/logged.

Instead use traceback.print_exc in the main handler to show the
traceback.

Change-Id: If84a41907e1fc782bd5a4608f445e75aa3a5d2fb
"}, {'created': '2018-07-20 16:07:47.000000000', 'message': "Log tracebacks

commit_message:
Log tracebacks

Always log the traceback for unexpected exceptions. It's very difficult
to tell where the error came from without the traceback.

It seems this was the intent with
Iad9de7fab0ee740bd20f8facd49f36e6f18d2fb1, but
traceback.format_exception doesn't actually print/log anything, it
returns a list of strings, which are just lost if not actually
saved/logged.

Instead use traceback.print_exc in the main handler to show the
traceback.

Change-Id: If84a41907e1fc782bd5a4608f445e75aa3a5d2fb

subject: Don't assume ansible_dir in finally clause
messages: [{'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2018-07-20 13:19:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 8532, 'date': '2018-07-20 18:32:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2018-07-21 00:23:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2018-07-21 00:23:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-20 13:19:07.000000000', 'message': "Don't assume ansible_dir in finally clause

As an exception can occur before ansible_dir is ever defined, we
shouldn't assume it exists in the main finally clause, otherwise an
Undefined exception could be thrown.

Instead, save ansbie_dir as a class variable and default it to None,
that way we can first check if it's been set before trying to use it in
finally.

Change-Id: I90e9718324b2f5e8420b89e8c00b5e366b82e96b
"}]
commit_message:
Don't assume ansible_dir in finally clause

As an exception can occur before ansible_dir is ever defined, we
shouldn't assume it exists in the main finally clause, otherwise an
Undefined exception could be thrown.

Instead, save ansbie_dir as a class variable and default it to None,
that way we can first check if it's been set before trying to use it in
finally.

Change-Id: I90e9718324b2f5e8420b89e8c00b5e366b82e96b

subject: Add --force-stack-create
messages: [{'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2018-07-20 12:46:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2018-07-21 00:22:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2018-07-23 20:21:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-20 12:46:10.000000000', 'message': "Add --force-stack-create

--force-stack-create will force the stack action to be CREATE when
UPDATE would otherwise be used. This is useful in scenarios when you had
a successful deployment, but did something wrong, so you want to froce a
recreate, for example when using a completely wrong roles file.

--force-stack-create and --force-stack-update are added to an argparse
mutually exclusive group so that both can't be specified at the same
time.

Also adds unit tests around the stack action handling and adds missing
unit tests for --force-stack-update.

Change-Id: Ia3edebfe2271710abc4b84ce090b9e7ddf3c9d88
"}]
commit_message:
Add --force-stack-create

--force-stack-create will force the stack action to be CREATE when
UPDATE would otherwise be used. This is useful in scenarios when you had
a successful deployment, but did something wrong, so you want to froce a
recreate, for example when using a completely wrong roles file.

--force-stack-create and --force-stack-update are added to an argparse
mutually exclusive group so that both can't be specified at the same
time.

Also adds unit tests around the stack action handling and adds missing
unit tests for --force-stack-update.

Change-Id: Ia3edebfe2271710abc4b84ce090b9e7ddf3c9d88

commit_message:
Support alias for webhook creation

This commit to support alias for webhook creation, to create webhook
use function_alias pramater, and get function_id and function_version
from function_alias. Also add function tests for webhook creation.

Change-Id: Ia5db0b446b6b0e0980da596ed073fa6e2d66d7cc
Story: #2002143

commit_message:
Generate rndc key in password list

We need this to be the same across all nodes in an ha environment,
so it has to be generated on the undercloud and passed in to the
deployment.

Change-Id: I469722466b93dfb97262211bb6f039cd78caa311

commit_message:
bump neutron-lib version to 1.14.0

This patch bumps the requirements and lower constraints to pick up
neutron-lib 1.14.0 so we can consume it.

Change-Id: Icb149785d938c64ff4d63f77bd8136b2ee364dd8

commit_message:
[Gate] Updating required neutron version for project

build-openstack-sphinx-docs gate was raising an error and -1 on the
gate, due to neutron out of date version (12.0.0). This patch will bring
neutron from 13.0.0.0b1 to newest version.

Error logs:
   ubuntu-xenial |     'router': constants.L3,
   ubuntu-xenial | AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute 'L3'
  
Please see more error logs in following link
http://logs.openstack.org/04/557904/8/check/build-openstack-sphinx-docs/7a6b1da/job-output.txt.gz#_2018-07-03_04_00_47_083795

Change-Id: Iebcadda5186f2f577c993276090aba2e99d13780

commit_message:
Extending designate named template to include "forwarders" parameter

To get forwarding to work in the kolla implementaion of designate,
I'm adding parameters to the named.conf.j2 template.  I'm adding
the ability to change the default values for dnssec-validation and
recursion and creating a new paramater for forwarders.

Change-Id: Ideef39034d75a0d99e8a3dc2a5f1a7203ccf51d5
Closes-Bug: #1781196

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-15 16:18:23.000000000', 'message': "Remove default pip_links value

The default pip_links is no longer useful for informing
pip of extra places to find wheels. With pypiserver
implemented it will serve all the wheels available on
the repo, so the find-links implementation is redundant.

Also, it's not working anyway. Pip delivers this error:

Skipping link http://x.x.x.x:8181/os-releases/y.y.y/ubuntu-16.04-x86_64/ (from -f); unsupported archive format: .04-x86_64

The pip_links variable can now just be used as a way of
telling pip about more wheel sources, rather than for
the wheels on the repo server.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/562544
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/563100
Change-Id: Ic3780ec0f449d0d5e8f17404964d7d967de28b76
Implements: blueprint python-build-install-simplification
Signed-off-by: Jesse Pretorius <jesse.pretorius@rackspace.co.uk>
(cherry picked from commit df760189c7d11777ccc4f45854b3c8078148dffc)
"}, {'created': '2018-05-18 16:31:06.000000000', 'message': "Remove default pip_links value

commit_message:
Remove default pip_links value

The default pip_links is no longer useful for informing
pip of extra places to find wheels. With pypiserver
implemented it will serve all the wheels available on
the repo, so the find-links implementation is redundant.

Also, it's not working anyway. Pip delivers this error:

Skipping link http://x.x.x.x:8181/os-releases/y.y.y/ubuntu-16.04-x86_64/ (from -f); unsupported archive format: .04-x86_64

The pip_links variable can now just be used as a way of
telling pip about more wheel sources, rather than for
the wheels on the repo server.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/562544
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/563100
Change-Id: Ic3780ec0f449d0d5e8f17404964d7d967de28b76
Implements: blueprint python-build-install-simplification
Signed-off-by: Jesse Pretorius <jesse.pretorius@rackspace.co.uk>
(cherry picked from commit df760189c7d11777ccc4f45854b3c8078148dffc)

commit_message:
Add close() to _RetryBody.

Allows clients to give up on reading the rest of the server response,
if they so choose.

Change-Id: Iccc95b1b5e7d066470966ee0c62a3beb260846e5

> It seems like the correct way to fix this would be to send the list of request specs to the scheduler instead of just taking the first one, but we can't do that because it would require an RPC bump for select_destinations. Is that right?

Yup. Plus, then we don't need the list of instance_uuids because each RequestSpec has an instance_uuid field in it - so we start to get into a mess about how much is too much and what's the long-term interface that we want? Because even RequestSpec.num_instances isn't needed anymore as long as instance_uuids is always passed in, and it should be since Pike.

We wouldn't need this change if we went with the alternative https://review.openstack.org/#/c/583351/ but that's got it's own issues, and I think this and that fix can co-exist. For example, I think the change to unset RequestSpec.instance_uuid when getting alternate hosts in *this* change is required regardless since it never made sense to run through the ServerGroupAntiAffinityFilter with a RequestSpec.instance_uuid set since you can't fail the selected host and hit an alternate that is the same host in an anti-affinity group."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-07-18 21:19:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-17 19:55:22.000000000', 'message': 'random hacking for bug 1781710

- quick patch to share with matt
https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1781710

Change-Id: Icba22060cb379ebd5e906981ec283667350b8c5a
'}, {'created': '2018-07-17 21:58:33.000000000', 'message': "Update RequestSpec.instance_uuid during scheduling

Before change I4b67ec9dd4ce846a704d0f75ad64c41e693de0fb
the ServerGroupAntiAffinityFilter did not rely on the
HostState.instances dict to determine **within the same
request** how many members of the same anti-affinity
group were on a given host. In fact, at that time, the
HostState.instances dict wasn't updated between filter
runs in the same multi-create request. That was fixed with
change Iacc636fa8a59a9e8670a8d683c10bdbb0dc8237b so that
as we select a host for each group member being created
within a single request, we also update the HostState.instances
dict so the ServerGroupAntiAffinityFilter would have
accurate tracking of which group members were on which
hosts.

However, that did not account for a wrinkle in the filter
added in change Ie016f59f5b98bb9c70b3e33556bd747f79fc77bd
which is needed to allow resizing a server to the same host
when that server is in an anti-affinity group. That wrinkle,
combined with the fact the RequestSpec the filter is acting
upon for a given instance in a multi-create request might
not actually have the same instance_uuid can cause the filter
to think it's in a resize situation and accept a host which
already has another member from the same anti-affinity group
on it, which breaks the anti-affinity policy.

For background, during a multi-create request, we create a
RequestSpec per instance being created, but conductor only
sends the first RequestSpec for the first instance to the
scheduler. This means RequestSpec.num_instances can be >1
and we can be processing the Nth instance in the list during
scheduling but working on a RequestSpec for the first instance.
That is what breaks the resize check in ServerGroupAntiAffinityFilter
with regard to multi-create.

To resolve this, we update the RequestSpec.instance_uuid when
filtering hosts for a given instance but we don't persist that
change to the RequestSpec. Also, when getting alternate hosts,
we have to unset the RequestSpec.instance_uuid before re-filtering
hosts in a multi-create request so that we don't run into the same
issue as during the initial filtering.

This is a bit clunky, but it kind of comes with the territory of
how we hack scheduling requests together using a single RequestSpec
for multi-create requests. An alternative to this is found in change
I0dd1fa5a70ac169efd509a50b5d69ee5deb8deb7 where we rely on the
RequestSpec.num_instances field to determine if we're in a multi-create
situation, but that has its own flaws because num_instances is
persisted with the RequestSpec which might cause us to re-introduce
bug 1558532 if we're not careful. In that case we'd have to either
(1) stop persisting RequestSpec.num_instances or (2) temporarily
unset it like we do using RequestSpec.reset_forced_destinations()
during move operations.

Co-Authored-By: Sean Mooney <work@seanmooney.info>

Closes-Bug: #1781710

Change-Id: Icba22060cb379ebd5e906981ec283667350b8c5a
"}, {'created': '2018-07-18 21:36:56.000000000', 'message': "Update RequestSpec.instance_uuid during scheduling

Before change I4b67ec9dd4ce846a704d0f75ad64c41e693de0fb
the ServerGroupAntiAffinityFilter did not rely on the
HostState.instances dict to determine **within the same
request** how many members of the same anti-affinity
group were on a given host. In fact, at that time, the
HostState.instances dict wasn't updated between filter
runs in the same multi-create request. That was fixed with
change Iacc636fa8a59a9e8670a8d683c10bdbb0dc8237b so that
as we select a host for each group member being created

accurate tracking of which group members were on which
hosts.

added in change Ie016f59f5b98bb9c70b3e33556bd747f79fc77bd
which is needed to allow resizing a server to the same host
when that server is in an anti-affinity group. That wrinkle,
combined with the fact the RequestSpec the filter is acting
upon for a given instance in a multi-create request might
not actually have the same instance_uuid can cause the filter
to think it's in a resize situation and accept a host which
already has another member from the same anti-affinity group
on it, which breaks the anti-affinity policy.

For background, during a multi-create request, we create a
RequestSpec per instance being created, but conductor only
sends the first RequestSpec for the first instance to the
scheduler. This means RequestSpec.num_instances can be >1
and we can be processing the Nth instance in the list during
scheduling but working on a RequestSpec for the first instance.
That is what breaks the resize check in ServerGroupAntiAffinityFilter
with regard to multi-create.

To resolve this, we update the RequestSpec.instance_uuid when
filtering hosts for a given instance but we don't persist that
change to the RequestSpec. Also, when getting alternate hosts,
we have to unset the RequestSpec.instance_uuid before re-filtering
hosts in a multi-create request so that we don't run into the same
issue as during the initial filtering.

This is a bit clunky, but it kind of comes with the territory of
how we hack scheduling requests together using a single RequestSpec
for multi-create requests. An alternative to this is found in change
I0dd1fa5a70ac169efd509a50b5d69ee5deb8deb7 where we rely on the
RequestSpec.num_instances field to determine if we're in a multi-create
situation, but that has its own flaws because num_instances is
persisted with the RequestSpec which might cause us to re-introduce
bug 1558532 if we're not careful. In that case we'd have to either
(1) stop persisting RequestSpec.num_instances or (2) temporarily
unset it like we do using RequestSpec.reset_forced_destinations()
during move operations.

Co-Authored-By: Sean Mooney <work@seanmooney.info>

Closes-Bug: #1781710

Change-Id: Icba22060cb379ebd5e906981ec283667350b8c5a

commit_message:
Update RequestSpec.instance_uuid during scheduling

Before change I4b67ec9dd4ce846a704d0f75ad64c41e693de0fb
the ServerGroupAntiAffinityFilter did not rely on the
HostState.instances dict to determine **within the same
request** how many members of the same anti-affinity
group were on a given host. In fact, at that time, the
HostState.instances dict wasn't updated between filter
runs in the same multi-create request. That was fixed with
change Iacc636fa8a59a9e8670a8d683c10bdbb0dc8237b so that
as we select a host for each group member being created
within a single request, we also update the HostState.instances
dict so the ServerGroupAntiAffinityFilter would have
accurate tracking of which group members were on which
hosts.

However, that did not account for a wrinkle in the filter
added in change Ie016f59f5b98bb9c70b3e33556bd747f79fc77bd
which is needed to allow resizing a server to the same host
when that server is in an anti-affinity group. That wrinkle,
combined with the fact the RequestSpec the filter is acting
upon for a given instance in a multi-create request might
not actually have the same instance_uuid can cause the filter
to think it's in a resize situation and accept a host which
already has another member from the same anti-affinity group
on it, which breaks the anti-affinity policy.

For background, during a multi-create request, we create a
RequestSpec per instance being created, but conductor only
sends the first RequestSpec for the first instance to the
scheduler. This means RequestSpec.num_instances can be >1
and we can be processing the Nth instance in the list during
scheduling but working on a RequestSpec for the first instance.
That is what breaks the resize check in ServerGroupAntiAffinityFilter
with regard to multi-create.

To resolve this, we update the RequestSpec.instance_uuid when
filtering hosts for a given instance but we don't persist that
change to the RequestSpec.

This is a bit clunky, but it kind of comes with the territory of
how we hack scheduling requests together using a single RequestSpec
for multi-create requests. An alternative to this is found in change
I0dd1fa5a70ac169efd509a50b5d69ee5deb8deb7 where we rely on the
RequestSpec.num_instances field to determine if we're in a multi-create
situation, but that has its own flaws because num_instances is
persisted with the RequestSpec which might cause us to re-introduce
bug 1558532 if we're not careful. In that case we'd have to either
(1) stop persisting RequestSpec.num_instances or (2) temporarily
unset it like we do using RequestSpec.reset_forced_destinations()
during move operations.

Co-Authored-By: Sean Mooney <work@seanmooney.info>

Closes-Bug: #1781710

Change-Id: Icba22060cb379ebd5e906981ec283667350b8c5a

commit_message:
Additional/alternative fix for bug 1781710

This is flawed since it would regress the ability to resize
to the same host for an instance in an anti-affinity group,
which was bug 1558532, but I wrote it before realizing that
so I'm posting it for discussion as an option (but we'd have
to deal with the persistent num_instances problem if we went
this route).

Change-Id: I0dd1fa5a70ac169efd509a50b5d69ee5deb8deb7
Related-Bug: #1781710

[1]. This patch updates the neutron-lib required version to match
neutron [1] in prep for the Rocky release.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/583671/

To work with neutron-lib 1.18.0, we need Rocky version of neutron,
so the minimum version of neutron is bumped to 13.0.0.0b2 (Rocky-2).

neutron itself), so the min version of SqlAlchemy is also bumped.

so the minimum version of neutron is bumped to 13.0.0.0b2 (Rocky-2).

We also need to bump the minimum version of SQLAlchemy. Rocky neutron
depends on pending_to_persistent ORM event in SQLAlchemy which was added
in SQLAlchemy 1.1. Rocky neutron now requires SqlAlchemy>=1.2.0,
so the min version of SQLAlchemy is bumped to 1.2.0.

Co-Authored-By: Akihiro Motoki <amotoki@gmail.com>

commit_message:
update requirements for neutron-lib 1.18.0

Neutron-lib 1.18.0 is our Rocky RC and is already being used by neutron
[1]. This patch updates the neutron-lib required version to match
neutron [1] in prep for the Rocky release.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/583671/

To work with neutron-lib 1.18.0, we need Rocky version of neutron,
so the minimum version of neutron is bumped to 13.0.0.0b2 (Rocky-2).

We also need to bump the minimum version of SQLAlchemy. Rocky neutron
depends on pending_to_persistent ORM event in SQLAlchemy which was added
in SQLAlchemy 1.1. Rocky neutron now requires SqlAlchemy>=1.2.0,
so the min version of SQLAlchemy is bumped to 1.2.0.

Co-Authored-By: Akihiro Motoki <amotoki@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I7c8c6c1b28e9dd85e192ec8d44e324e135419cbd

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-15 07:59:35.000000000', 'message': 'Ensure that the repo servers also use the pypi cache

When re-running openstack-hosts after a greenfield deployment
the repo servers will be reconfigured to make use of the pypi
cache implemented on the repo host. There is therefore no
real reason why it should not be done sooner during the
greenfield deploy - otherwise the deployment is inconsistent.

Also, in a situation where the deployment has no containers,
not implementing the configuration to use the repo pypi cache
results in the rest of the deployment not being able to find
the packages which were built from source. It instead makes
all pip installs go to pypi and never even attempt the cache.

Finally, once the repo build is complete the repo-use playbook
is run to ensure that pip is reconfigured to use it - but the
facts to set the default pip index were set prior to the repo
being built, so the reconfiguration leaves the default pip
index to that of pypi. as such, in this patch, we re-verify
and re-set the applicable vars to ensure that the repo is used.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/563106
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/563111
Change-Id: I2e7f9bc6cbf15b3309f843ffc24b4643563906a0
(cherry picked from commit 6677e1ef8f60ee64720288b748a19517a09f209d)
'}, {'created': '2018-05-18 16:30:58.000000000', 'message': 'Ensure that the repo servers also use the pypi cache

'}, {'created': '2018-07-19 18:56:46.000000000', 'message': 'Ensure that the repo servers also use the pypi cache

When re-running openstack-hosts after a greenfield deployment
the repo servers will be reconfigured to make use of the pypi
cache implemented on the repo host. There is therefore no
real reason why it should not be done sooner during the
greenfield deploy - otherwise the deployment is inconsistent.

Also, in a situation where the deployment has no containers,
not implementing the configuration to use the repo pypi cache
results in the rest of the deployment not being able to find
the packages which were built from source. It instead makes
all pip installs go to pypi and never even attempt the cache.

Finally, once the repo build is complete the repo-use playbook
is run to ensure that pip is reconfigured to use it - but the
facts to set the default pip index were set prior to the repo
being built, so the reconfiguration leaves the default pip
index to that of pypi. as such, in this patch, we re-verify
and re-set the applicable vars to ensure that the repo is used.

commit_message:
Ensure that the repo servers also use the pypi cache

When re-running openstack-hosts after a greenfield deployment
the repo servers will be reconfigured to make use of the pypi
cache implemented on the repo host. There is therefore no
real reason why it should not be done sooner during the
greenfield deploy - otherwise the deployment is inconsistent.

Also, in a situation where the deployment has no containers,
not implementing the configuration to use the repo pypi cache
results in the rest of the deployment not being able to find
the packages which were built from source. It instead makes
all pip installs go to pypi and never even attempt the cache.

Finally, once the repo build is complete the repo-use playbook
is run to ensure that pip is reconfigured to use it - but the
facts to set the default pip index were set prior to the repo
being built, so the reconfiguration leaves the default pip
index to that of pypi. as such, in this patch, we re-verify
and re-set the applicable vars to ensure that the repo is used.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/563106
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/563111
Change-Id: I2e7f9bc6cbf15b3309f843ffc24b4643563906a0
(cherry picked from commit 6677e1ef8f60ee64720288b748a19517a09f209d)

[{'created': '2018-04-26 08:18:42.000000000', 'message': "Ensure that repo checks use the right values

When executing the check for the appropriate files on
the repo host and then overriding the group_vars to
cater for when the repo is not present, we need to make
sure that we're doing the checks against the right URL.

In this patch we backup the default URL so that it can
be used when re-executing the check later in the same
playbook.

Also, given that the set-pip-upstream-url.yml and
set-upper-constraints.yml task sets are always used
together, we combine them into one task set.

Conflicts:
>------playbooks/containers-nspawn-create.yml

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/563962
Change-Id: I040c4f5b6e96c85c68beb975f7b80d1edf42276d

commit_message:
Ensure that repo checks use the right values

When executing the check for the appropriate files on
the repo host and then overriding the group_vars to
cater for when the repo is not present, we need to make
sure that we're doing the checks against the right URL.

In this patch we backup the default URL so that it can
be used when re-executing the check later in the same
playbook.

Also, given that the set-pip-upstream-url.yml and
set-upper-constraints.yml task sets are always used
together, we combine them into one task set.

Conflicts:
>------playbooks/containers-nspawn-create.yml

Change-Id: I040c4f5b6e96c85c68beb975f7b80d1edf42276d
(cherry picked from commit 792c753354381a030f11b949cd159c329c5cfdfe)

This patchset moves service validation helper function out of
policy_authority module into rbac_rule_validation, because
service validation should be placed in a high-level module
that covers both policy_authority and requirements_authority.

The unit tests are also moved and refactored as appropriate.

Note that in the future further refactoring might be required
to make service validation use Tempest's is_service_available
function or references to Tempest's service_available
configuration group for code simplification.

Change-Id: I330e1e047e0be73b40d06a3c04caa204ab92d984

commit_message:
Move service validation to rbac_rule_validation

This patchset moves service validation helper function out of
policy_authority module into rbac_rule_validation, because
service validation should be placed in a high-level module
that covers both policy_authority and requirements_authority.

Additionally, the service validation logic is refactored
to use Tempest's get_service_list() under tempest.common.utils
because:

* this approach is configuration driven
* more efficient
* simpler
* uses supported Tempest function

The unit tests are also moved and refactored as appropriate.

I have added a task in the story https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/story/2001585 to track the tempest work'}, {'account_id': 21781, 'date': '2018-07-24 01:12:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 6732, 'date': '2018-07-24 01:30:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-20 09:18:53.000000000', 'message': 'Kubernetes: disable inter-pods connections

By default pods in Kubernetes can connect to each other. However in
Qinling, each pod should be independent acting as a worker of a function
or running an execution of a function. Disabling the inter-pods traffic
in the namespace used by Qinling would ensure the isolation of each pod.

This commit leverages the NetworkPolicy in Kubernetes[1] to isolate the
pods. So a network solution which supports NetworkPolicy (for example,
cailco) for Kubernetes must be used or there will be no effect.

[1] https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/services-networking/network-policies/

Story: 2001585
Task: 6534
Change-Id: I368323410e92cc23c9a7b50e4936c7070cd57ef7
'}, {'created': '2018-07-23 08:56:43.000000000', 'message': 'Kubernetes: disable inter-pods connections

This commit leverages the NetworkPolicy in Kubernetes[1] to isolate the
pods. So a network solution which supports NetworkPolicy (for example,
cailco) for Kubernetes must be used or there will be no effect.

[1] https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/services-networking/network-policies/

Change-Id: I368323410e92cc23c9a7b50e4936c7070cd57ef7

Change-Id: I368323410e92cc23c9a7b50e4936c7070cd57ef7
'}]
commit_message:
Kubernetes: disable inter-pods connections

By default pods in Kubernetes can connect to each other. However in
Qinling, each pod should be independent acting as a worker of a function
or running an execution of a function. Disabling the inter-pods traffic
in the namespace used by Qinling would ensure the isolation of each pod.

This commit leverages the NetworkPolicy in Kubernetes[1] to isolate the
pods. So a network solution which supports NetworkPolicy (for example,
cailco) for Kubernetes must be used or there will be no effect.

[1] https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/services-networking/network-policies/

Story: 2001585
Task: 6534
Change-Id: I368323410e92cc23c9a7b50e4936c7070cd57ef7

commit_message:
Implement OVO for Barbican [3]

This patch set is to create a Base class OVO and
implement some model classes like below:

- Container
- ContainerACL
- ContainerACLUser
- ContainerCosumerMetadatum
- ContainerSecret

Change-Id: I641811388292d1ad71dbd19935d2785c94da7b73
Co-Authored-By: Kien Nguyen <kiennt@vn.fujitsu.com>
Partial-Implements: blueprint rolling-upgrade

don't need to be documented, since they present
no meaningful information to contributors.

Removing these also avoids the docstring
formatting issues that ddt may introduce
to the sphinx build. [1]

commit_message:
[Docs] Don't include unittest documentation

The `test_quota` and `test_policy` modules
don't need to be documented, since they present
no meaningful information to contributors.

Removing these also avoids the docstring
formatting issues that ddt may introduce
to the sphinx build. [1]

[1] https://github.com/datadriventests/ddt/pull/51

Change-Id: I8136e8a000e04bcc213a746c7d793bf9373b1b38
Closes-Bug: #1783124

Neutron-lib 1.18.0 is our Rocky RC and is already being used by neutron

commit_message:
update requirements for neutron-lib 1.18.0

Neutron-lib 1.18.0 is our Rocky RC and is already being used by neutron
[1]. This patch updates the neutron-lib required version to match
neutron [1] in prep for the Rocky release.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/583671/

Change-Id: Ied1f59a4027fc0df29ede6243620eb876b3ae75f

subject: Enable logging to stdout/stderr in memcached
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 6926, 'name': 'Bogdan Dobrelya', 'email': 'bdobreli@redhat.com', 'username': 'bogdando'}, {'_account_id': 14985, 'name': 'Alex Schultz', 'email': 'aschultz@next-development.com', 'username': 'mwhahaha'}, {'_account_id': 20172, 'name': 'Michele Baldessari', 'email': 'michele@acksyn.org', 'username': 'michele'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23181, 'name': 'RDO Third Party CI', 'email': 'dmsimard+rdothirdparty@redhat.com', 'username': 'rdothirdparty', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-17 19:30:24.000000000', 'message': 'WIP Enable logging to stdout/stderr in memcached

Even though https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1776889 got fixed,
memcached is still configured to log to a file due to the way
puppet-memcached works:
- It would omit logging to a file when the logfile parameter (which has
  a default value) is set to undef
- In puppet/hiera undeffing a parameter that has a default value does
  not work: https://tickets.puppetlabs.com/browse/PUP-5295

In fact even after the fixes from https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1776889 get included we still see the following:
[root@rhosp-ctr01 ~]# ps -ef | grep memcached
42457 44366 44342 0 10:06 ? 00:00:00 /bin/bash -c source /etc/sysconfig/memcached; /usr/bin/memcached -p ${PORT} -u ${USER} -m ${CACHESIZE} -c ${MAXCONN} $OPTIONS
42457 44385 44366 0 10:06 ? 00:00:08 /usr/bin/memcached -p 11211 -u memcached -m 16005 -c 8192 -v -l 192.168.18.11 -U 0 -t 8 >> /var/log/memcached.log 2>&1

This change depends on the following memcached PR:
https://github.com/saz/puppet-memcached/pull/99/files to work correctly.

With this patch memcached logs to stdout/err correctly:

commit_message:
Enable logging to stdout/stderr in memcached

Even though https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1776889 got fixed,
memcached is still configured to log to a file due to the way
puppet-memcached works:
- It would omit logging to a file when the logfile parameter (which has
  a default value) is set to undef
- In puppet/hiera undeffing a parameter that has a default value does
  not work: https://tickets.puppetlabs.com/browse/PUP-5295

In fact even after the fixes from https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1776889 get included we still see the following:
[root@rhosp-ctr01 ~]# ps -ef | grep memcached
42457 44366 44342 0 10:06 ? 00:00:00 /bin/bash -c source /etc/sysconfig/memcached; /usr/bin/memcached -p ${PORT} -u ${USER} -m ${CACHESIZE} -c ${MAXCONN} $OPTIONS
42457 44385 44366 0 10:06 ? 00:00:08 /usr/bin/memcached -p 11211 -u memcached -m 16005 -c 8192 -v -l 192.168.18.11 -U 0 -t 8 >> /var/log/memcached.log 2>&1

This change depends on the following memcached PR:
https://github.com/saz/puppet-memcached/pull/99/files to work correctly.

With this patch memcached logs to stdout/err correctly:
[root@overcloud-controller-0 etc]# ps auxwfw |grep memcache
42457      37207  0.0  0.0  11680  1396 ?        Ss   19:23   0:00      |   \_ /bin/bash -c source /etc/sysconfig/memcached; /usr/bin/memcached -p ${PORT} -u ${USER} -m ${CACHESIZE} -c ${MAXCONN} $OPTIONS
42457      37224  0.0  0.0 293160  3724 ?        Sl   19:23   0:00      |       \_ /usr/bin/memcached -p 11211 -u memcached -m 5877 -c 8192 -v -l 172.16.2.14 -U 0 -X -t 2

Change-Id: I8cec029bd1f64ec1daa76a89e949e7d245580918
Closes-Bug: #1782223

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-02 14:44:52.000000000', 'message': "ControlPlaneDefaultRoute using get_attr

Use get_attr on the server resource to resolve attribute
value from the subnet(s) and pass it to the parameter
'ControlPlaneDefaultRoute' used in the THT/network/config/*
templates.

Changes the default for 'ControlPlaneDefaultRoute' to ''
as well as the comment that the value should be overriden
in parameters_defaults. It also removes the parameter from
network-environment templates.

A conditinal is used in  puppet/role.role.j2.yaml so that
the parameter value is used whenever it is not '' (the
default) to provide backwards compatibility in case the
user set a different value (different from the one used in
undercloud.conf) for this parameter in
network-environment.yaml.

When deploying a routed control plane the network config
templates would previously need to be updated to carry
'ControlPlaneXDefaultRoute' parameters for each leaf. With
8 Leafs in addition to the network local to the undercloud
that is 8 parameters less to place in the configuration.
By getting the value to pass from the server resource this
change reduces the required nic-config template
customisation (reduces the risk of user error).

Partial: blueprint tripleo-routed-networks-templates
Change-Id: I5139249d55e9ac01761c270b8c0f31ef35595940

commit_message:
ControlPlaneDefaultRoute using get_attr

Use get_attr on the server resource to resolve attribute
value from the subnet(s) and pass it to the parameter
'ControlPlaneDefaultRoute' used in the THT/network/config/*
templates.

Changes the default for 'ControlPlaneDefaultRoute' to ''
as well as the comment that the value should be overriden
in parameters_defaults. It also removes the parameter from
network-environment templates.

A conditinal is used in  puppet/role.role.j2.yaml so that
the parameter value is used whenever it is not '' (the
default) to provide backwards compatibility in case the
user set a different value (different from the one used in
undercloud.conf) for this parameter in
network-environment.yaml.

When deploying a routed control plane the network config
templates would previously need to be updated to carry
'ControlPlaneXDefaultRoute' parameters for each leaf. With
8 Leafs in addition to the network local to the undercloud
that is 8 parameters less to place in the configuration.
By getting the value to pass from the server resource this
change reduces the required nic-config template
customisation (reduces the risk of user error).

Partial: blueprint tripleo-routed-networks-templates
Change-Id: I5139249d55e9ac01761c270b8c0f31ef35595940

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-02 14:44:52.000000000', 'message': "ControlPlaneSubnetCidr using get_attr

Use get_attr on the server resource to resolve attribute
value from the subnet(s) and pass it to the parameter
'ControlPlaneSubnetCidr' used in the THT/network/config/*
templates.

As the value is now resolved from resource attributes,
this changes the default for 'ControlPlaneSubnetCidr' to ''
as well as the comment that these value should be overriden
in parameters_defaults. It also removes the parameter from
network-environment templates.

A conditinal is used in  puppet/role.role.j2.yaml so that
the parameter value is used whenever it is not '' (the
default) to provide backwards compatibility in case the user
set a different value (different from the one used in
undercloud.conf) for this parameter in
network-environment.yaml.

When deploying a routed control plane the network config
templates would previously need to be updated to carry
'ControlPlaneXSubnetCidr' parameter (in case the subnet
mask is not the same for all the routed network leafs).
With 8 Leafs in addition to the network local to the
undercloud that is 8 parameters less to place in the
configuration. By getting the value to pass from the
server resource this change reduces the required nic-config
template customisation (reduces the risk of user error).

Partial: blueprint tripleo-routed-networks-templates
Change-Id: I92ee0f9a2107cdf1ca5903d3756a235a79c36c73
